title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement david@schochastics.net. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to graphlayouts
text: outlines propose change graphlayouts. detailed info contributing , tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide.

title: Contributing to graphlayouts
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to graphlayouts
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to graphlayouts
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("schochastics/graphlayouts", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to graphlayouts
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: graphlayouts
text: package implements following algorithms: Stress majorization (Paper) Quadrilateral backbone layout (Paper) flexible radial layouts (Paper) sparse stress (Paper) pivot MDS (Paper) dynamic layout longitudinal data (Paper) spectral layouts (adjacency/Laplacian) simple multilevel layout layout algorithm using UMAP group based centrality focus layouts keeps groups nodes close range concentric circle

title: graphlayouts
text: “stress” layout always safe layout choice since deterministic produces nice plots almost graph. recommended use default choice.
code: set.seed(666) pa <- sample_pa(1000,1,1,directed = F)  ggraph(pa,layout = "stress")+   geom_edge_link0(width = 0.2,colour = "grey")+   geom_node_point(color = "black",size = 0.3)+   theme_graph()

title: graphlayouts
text: Stress majorization also works networks several components. relies bin packing algorithm efficiently put components rectangle, rather circle.
code: set.seed(666) g <- disjoint_union(   sample_pa(10,directed = F),   sample_pa(20,directed = F),   sample_pa(30,directed = F),   sample_pa(40,directed = F),   sample_pa(50,directed = F),   sample_pa(60,directed = F),   sample_pa(80,directed = F) )  ggraph(g, layout = "stress",bbox = 40) +   geom_edge_link0() +   geom_node_point() +   theme_graph()

title: graphlayouts
text: layout_as_backbone() layout algorithm can help emphasize hidden group structures. illustrate performance algorithm, create artificial network subtle group structure using sample_islands() igraph. network consists 9 groups 40 vertices . density within group 0.4 15 edges running pair groups. Using recommended approach using stress layout yields following result.  one can see, graph seems proper hairball without special structural features standing . case, though, know 9 groups vertices internally densely connected externally. uncover group structure, turn backbone layout. backbone layout helps uncover potential group structures based edge embeddedness puts emphasis structure layout. use function, need install package oaqc  groups now clearly visible. course network used example specifically tailored illustrate power algorithm. Using backbone layout real world networks may always result clear division groups. thus seen universal remedy drawing hairball networks. Keep mind: can emphasize hidden group structure exists.
code: set.seed(665) #create network with a group structure g <- sample_islands(9,40,0.4,15) g <- simplify(g) V(g)$grp <- as.character(rep(1:9,each=40))  ggraph(g,layout = "stress")+   geom_edge_link0(colour = rgb(0,0,0,0.5),width = 0.1)+   geom_node_point(aes(col = grp))+   scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1")+   theme_graph()+   theme(legend.position = "none") install.packages("oaqc") bb <- layout_as_backbone(g,keep=0.4) E(g)$col <- F E(g)$col[bb$backbone] <- T  ggraph(g,layout = "manual",x = bb$xy[,1],y = bb$xy[,2])+   geom_edge_link0(aes(color = col),width = 0.1)+   geom_node_point(aes(color = grp))+   scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1")+   scale_edge_color_manual(values = c(rgb(0,0,0,0.3),rgb(0,0,0,1)))+   theme_graph()+   theme(legend.position = "none")

title: graphlayouts
text: function layout_with_focus() creates radial layout around focal node. nodes distance focal node circle.
code: karate <- make_graph("Zachary")  p1 <- ggraph(karate,layout = "focus",focus = 1) +   draw_circle(use = "focus",max.circle = 3)+   geom_edge_link0(edge_color="black",edge_width=0.3)+   geom_node_point(fill="grey25", size=2,shape=21)+   scale_fill_manual(values=c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E"))+   theme_graph()+   theme(legend.position = "none")+   coord_fixed()+   labs(title= "Focus on Mr. Hi")  p2 <- ggraph(karate,layout = "focus",focus = 34) +   draw_circle(use = "focus",max.circle = 4)+   geom_edge_link0(edge_color="black",edge_width=0.3)+   geom_node_point(fill="grey25",size=2,shape=21)+   scale_fill_manual(values=c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E"))+   theme_graph()+   theme(legend.position = "none")+   coord_fixed()+   labs(title= "Focus on John A.")  p1 p2

title: graphlayouts
text: function layout_with_centrality creates radial layout around node highest centrality value. outside node , peripheral .
code: bc <- betweenness(karate) p1 <- ggraph(karate,layout = "centrality", centrality = bc, tseq = seq(0,1,0.15)) +   draw_circle(use = "cent") +   annotate_circle(bc,format="",pos="bottom") +   geom_edge_link0(edge_color="black",edge_width=0.3)+   geom_node_point(fill="grey25", size=2,shape=21)+   scale_fill_manual(values=c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E"))+   theme_graph()+   theme(legend.position = "none")+   coord_fixed()+   labs(title="betweenness centrality")   cc <- closeness(karate) p2 <- ggraph(karate,layout = "centrality", centrality = cc, tseq = seq(0,1,0.2)) +   draw_circle(use = "cent") +   annotate_circle(cc,format="scientific",pos="bottom") +   geom_edge_link0(edge_color="black",edge_width=0.3)+   geom_node_point(fill="grey25",size=2,shape=21)+   scale_fill_manual(values=c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E"))+   theme_graph()+   theme(legend.position = "none")+   coord_fixed()+   labs(title="closeness centrality")  p1 p2

title: graphlayouts
text: graphlayouts implements two algorithms visualizing large networks (<100k nodes). layout_with_pmds() similar layout_with_mds() performs multidimensional scaling small number pivot nodes. Usually, 50-100 enough obtain similar results full MDS. layout_with_sparse_stress() performs stress majorization small number pivots (~50-100). runtime performance inferior pivotMDS quality far superior.

title: graphlayouts
text: functions layout_mirror() layout_rotate() can used manipulate existing layout

what: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: package implements graph layout algorithms available igraph. detailed introductory tutorial graphlayouts ggraph can found . package implements following algorithms: Stress majorization (Paper) Quadrilateral backbone layout (Paper) flexible radial layouts (Paper) sparse stress (Paper) pivot MDS (Paper) dynamic layout longitudinal data (Paper) spectral layouts (adjacency/Laplacian) simple multilevel layout layout algorithm using UMAP group based centrality focus layouts keeps groups nodes close range concentric circle

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
code: # dev version remotes::install_github("schochastics/graphlayouts")  # CRAN install.packages("graphlayouts")

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: example bit special case since exploits weird issues igraph.
code: library(igraph) library(ggraph) library(graphlayouts)  set.seed(666) pa <- sample_pa(1000, 1, 1, directed = F)  ggraph(pa, layout = "nicely") +     geom_edge_link0(width = 0.2, colour = "grey") +     geom_node_point(col = "black", size = 0.3) +     theme_graph() ggraph(pa, layout = "stress") +     geom_edge_link0(width = 0.2, colour = "grey") +     geom_node_point(col = "black", size = 0.3) +     theme_graph()

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: Stress majorization also works networks several components. relies bin packing algorithm efficiently put components rectangle, rather circle.
code: set.seed(666) g <- disjoint_union(     sample_pa(10, directed = FALSE),     sample_pa(20, directed = FALSE),     sample_pa(30, directed = FALSE),     sample_pa(40, directed = FALSE),     sample_pa(50, directed = FALSE),     sample_pa(60, directed = FALSE),     sample_pa(80, directed = FALSE) )  ggraph(g, layout = "nicely") +     geom_edge_link0() +     geom_node_point() +     theme_graph() ggraph(g, layout = "stress", bbox = 40) +     geom_edge_link0() +     geom_node_point() +     theme_graph()

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: Backbone layouts helpful drawing hairballs.  backbone layout helps uncover potential group structures based edge embeddedness puts emphasis structure layout. use function, need install package oaqc
code: set.seed(665) # create network with a group structure g <- sample_islands(9, 40, 0.4, 15) g <- simplify(g) V(g)$grp <- as.character(rep(1:9, each = 40))  ggraph(g, layout = "stress") +     geom_edge_link0(colour = rgb(0, 0, 0, 0.5), width = 0.1) +     geom_node_point(aes(col = grp)) +     scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +     theme_graph() +     theme(legend.position = "none") install.packages("oaqc") bb <- layout_as_backbone(g, keep = 0.4) E(g)$col <- F E(g)$col[bb$backbone] <- T  ggraph(g, layout = "manual", x = bb$xy[, 1], y = bb$xy[, 2]) +     geom_edge_link0(aes(col = col), width = 0.1) +     geom_node_point(aes(col = grp)) +     scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +     scale_edge_color_manual(values = c(rgb(0, 0, 0, 0.3), rgb(0, 0, 0, 1))) +     theme_graph() +     theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: function layout_with_focus() creates radial layout around focal node. nodes distance focal node circle.
code: library(igraphdata) library(patchwork) data("karate")  p1 <- ggraph(karate, layout = "focus", focus = 1) +     draw_circle(use = "focus", max.circle = 3) +     geom_edge_link0(edge_color = "black", edge_width = 0.3) +     geom_node_point(aes(fill = as.factor(Faction)), size = 2, shape = 21) +     scale_fill_manual(values = c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E")) +     theme_graph() +     theme(legend.position = "none") +     coord_fixed() +     labs(title = "Focus on Mr. Hi")  p2 <- ggraph(karate, layout = "focus", focus = 34) +     draw_circle(use = "focus", max.circle = 4) +     geom_edge_link0(edge_color = "black", edge_width = 0.3) +     geom_node_point(aes(fill = as.factor(Faction)), size = 2, shape = 21) +     scale_fill_manual(values = c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E")) +     theme_graph() +     theme(legend.position = "none") +     coord_fixed() +     labs(title = "Focus on John A.")  p1 + p2

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: function layout_with_centrality creates radial layout around node highest centrality value. outside node , peripheral .
code: library(igraphdata) library(patchwork) data("karate")  bc <- betweenness(karate) p1 <- ggraph(karate, layout = "centrality", centrality = bc, tseq = seq(0, 1, 0.15)) +     draw_circle(use = "cent") +     annotate_circle(bc, format = "", pos = "bottom") +     geom_edge_link0(edge_color = "black", edge_width = 0.3) +     geom_node_point(aes(fill = as.factor(Faction)), size = 2, shape = 21) +     scale_fill_manual(values = c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E")) +     theme_graph() +     theme(legend.position = "none") +     coord_fixed() +     labs(title = "betweenness centrality")   cc <- closeness(karate) p2 <- ggraph(karate, layout = "centrality", centrality = cc, tseq = seq(0, 1, 0.2)) +     draw_circle(use = "cent") +     annotate_circle(cc, format = "scientific", pos = "bottom") +     geom_edge_link0(edge_color = "black", edge_width = 0.3) +     geom_node_point(aes(fill = as.factor(Faction)), size = 2, shape = 21) +     scale_fill_manual(values = c("#8B2323", "#EEAD0E")) +     theme_graph() +     theme(legend.position = "none") +     coord_fixed() +     labs(title = "closeness centrality")  p1 + p2

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: graphlayouts implements two algorithms visualizing large networks (<100k nodes). layout_with_pmds() similar layout_with_mds() performs multidimensional scaling small number pivot nodes. Usually, 50-100 enough obtain similar results full MDS. layout_with_sparse_stress() performs stress majorization small number pivots (~50-100). runtime performance inferior pivotMDS quality far superior. comparison runtimes layout quality can found wikitl;dr: layout algorithms appear faster fastest igraph algorithm layout_with_drl(). two examples layouts generated large graphs using layout_with_sparse_stress() retweet network 18k nodes 61k edges network football players 165K nodes 6M edges.

title: Additional Layout Algorithms for Network Visualizations
text: layout_as_dynamic() allows visualize snapshots longitudinal network data. Nodes anchored reference layout moved slightly wave depending deleted/added edges. way, easy track specific nodes throughout time. Use patchwork put individual plots next .
code: # remotes::install_github("schochastics/networkdata") library(networkdata) # longitudinal dataset of friendships in a school class data("s50")  xy <- layout_as_dynamic(s50, alpha = 0.2) pList <- vector("list", length(s50))  for (i in seq_along(s50)) {     pList[[i]] <- ggraph(s50[[i]], layout = "manual", x = xy[[i]][, 1], y = xy[[i]][, 2]) +         geom_edge_link0(edge_width = 0.6, edge_colour = "grey66") +         geom_node_point(shape = 21, aes(fill = as.factor(smoke)), size = 3) +         geom_node_text(aes(label = 1:50), repel = T) +         scale_fill_manual(             values = c("forestgreen", "grey25", "firebrick"),             labels = c("no", "occasional", "regular"),             name = "smoking",             guide = ifelse(i != 2, "none", "legend")         ) +         theme_graph() +         theme(legend.position = "bottom") +         labs(title = paste0("Wave ", i)) } wrap_plots(pList)

title: annotate concentric circles — annotate_circle
code: library(igraph) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘igraph’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     decompose, spectrum #> The following object is masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     union library(ggraph) #> Loading required package: ggplot2  g <- sample_gnp(10, 0.4) if (FALSE) { ggraph(g, layout = "centrality", centrality = closeness(g)) +   draw_circle(use = "cent") +   annotate_circle(closeness(g), pos = "bottom", format = "scientific") +   geom_edge_link() +   geom_node_point(shape = 21, fill = "grey25", size = 5) +   theme_graph() +   coord_fixed() }

what: graphlayouts: layout algorithms for network visualizations — graphlayouts-package
title: graphlayouts: layout algorithms for network visualizations — graphlayouts-package
text: package implements several new layout algorithms visualize networks. based concept stress majorization. specific algorithms allow emphasize hidden group structures networks focus specific nodes. package best used conjunction ggraph. features package : layout_with_stress() state art deterministic layout algorithms. layout_as_backbone() uncovers hidden group structures (exist) emphasizing strongly embedded edges. layout_with_focus() layout_with_centrality() produce concentric layouts focal central nodes center. layout_with_eigen() implements layout algorithms basis eigenvectors layout_with_sparse_stress() sparse stress large graphs layout_with_pmds() pivot MDS large graphs. layout_as_dynamic() longitudinal network data detailed tutorial can found https://www.mr.schochastics.net/material/netVizR/

title: graphlayouts: layout algorithms for network visualizations — graphlayouts-package
text: Maintainer: David Schoch david@schochastics.net (ORCID)

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
text: Metro map layout based multicriteria optimization

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
code: layout_as_metromap(object, xy, l = 2, gr = 0.0025, w = rep(1, 5), bsize = 5)

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
text: object original graph xy initial layout original graph l desired multiple grid point spacing. (l*gr determines desired edge length) gr grid spacing. (l*gr determines desired edge length) w weight vector criteria (see details) bsize number grid points station can move away rom original position

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
text: new coordinates stations

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
text: function optimizes following five criteria using hill climbing algorithm: Angular Resolution Criterion: angles incident edges station maximized, small angle two adjacent edges, can become difficult distinguish Edge Length Criterion: edge lengths across whole map approximately equal ensure regular spacing stations. based preferred multiple, l, grid spacing, g. purpose criterion penalize edges longer shorter lg. Balanced Edge Length Criterion: length edges incident particular station similar Line Straightness Criterion: (yet implemented) Edges form part line , possible, co-linear either side station line passes Octiinearity Criterion: edge drawn horizontally, vertically, diagonally 45 degree, penalize edges desired angle

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
text: Stott, Jonathan, et al. "Automatic metro map layout using multicriteria optimization." IEEE Transactions Visualization Computer Graphics 17.1 (2010): 101-114.

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
text: David Schoch

title: Metro Map Layout — layout_as_metromap
code: # the algorithm has problems with parallel edges library(igraph) g <- simplify(metro_berlin) xy <- cbind(V(g)$lon, V(g)$lat) * 100  # the algorithm is not very stable. try playing with the parameters xy_new <- layout_as_metromap(g, xy, l = 2, gr = 0.5, w = c(100, 100, 1, 1, 100), bsize = 35)

title: backbone graph layout — layout_backbone
text: emphasizes hidden group structure exists graph. Calculates layout sparsified network including embedded edges. Deleted edges added back layout calculated.

title: backbone graph layout — layout_backbone
code: layout_as_backbone(g, keep = 0.2, backbone = TRUE)  layout_igraph_backbone(g, keep = 0.2, backbone = TRUE, circular)

title: backbone graph layout — layout_backbone
text: g igraph object keep fraction edges keep backbone calculation backbone logical. Return edge ids backbone (Default: TRUE) circular used

title: backbone graph layout — layout_backbone
text: list xy coordinates vector edge ids included backbone

title: backbone graph layout — layout_backbone
text: layout_igraph_* function used directly. used argument plotting 'igraph'. 'ggraph' natively supports layout.

title: backbone graph layout — layout_backbone
text: Nocaj, ., Ortmann, M., & Brandes, U. (2015). Untangling hairballs multi-centered, small-world online social media networks. Journal Graph Algorithms Applications: JGAA, 19(2), 595-618.

title: backbone graph layout — layout_backbone
code: library(igraph)  g <- sample_islands(9, 20, 0.4, 9) g <- simplify(g) V(g)$grp <- as.character(rep(1:9, each = 20)) bb <- layout_as_backbone(g, keep = 0.4)  # add backbone links as edge attribute E(g)$col <- FALSE E(g)$col[bb$backbone] <- TRUE

title: radial centrality layout — layout_centrality

title: radial centrality layout — layout_centrality
code: layout_with_centrality(   g,   cent,   scale = TRUE,   iter = 500,   tol = 1e-04,   tseq = seq(0, 1, 0.2) )  layout_igraph_centrality(   g,   cent,   scale = TRUE,   iter = 500,   tol = 1e-04,   tseq = seq(0, 1, 0.2),   circular )

title: radial centrality layout — layout_centrality
text: g igraph object cent centrality scores scale logical. centrality scores scaled \([0,100]\)? (Default: TRUE) iter number iterations stress optimization tol stopping criterion stress optimization tseq numeric vector. increasing sequence coefficients combine regular stress constraint stress. See details. circular used

text: matrix xy coordinates

title: radial centrality layout — layout_centrality
text: function optimizes convex combination regular stress constrained stress function forces nodes arranged concentric circles. vector tseq sequence parameters used convex combination. iteration algorithm \(tseq[]\) used combine regular constraint stress \((1-tseq[])*stress_{regular}+tseq[]*stress_{constraint}\). sequence must increasing, start zero end one. default setting good choice graphs. layout_igraph_* function used directly. used argument plotting 'igraph'. 'ggraph' natively supports layout.

title: radial centrality layout — layout_centrality
text: Brandes, U., & Pich, C. (2011). flexible radial layout. Journal Graph Algorithms Applications, 15(1), 157-173.

title: radial centrality layout — layout_centrality
code: library(igraph) library(ggraph)  g <- sample_gnp(10, 0.4) if (FALSE) { ggraph(g, layout = "centrality", centrality = closeness(g)) +     draw_circle(use = "cent") +     geom_edge_link0() +     geom_node_point(shape = 21, fill = "grey25", size = 5) +     theme_graph() +     coord_fixed() }

title: dynamic graph layout — layout_dynamic
text: reference layout calculated based union graphs. parameter alpha controls influence reference layout. alpha=1, reference layout used graphs layout. alpha=0, stress layout individual graph used. Values -interpolate two layouts. careful using weights. cases, inverse edge weights used ensure endpoints edges higher weights closer together (weights=1/E(g)$weight).

title: multilevel layout — layout_multilevel
text: Layout algorithm visualize multilevel networks

title: multilevel layout — layout_multilevel
code: layout_as_multilevel(   g,   type = "all",   FUN1,   FUN2,   params1 = NULL,   params2 = NULL,   ignore_iso = TRUE,   project2D = TRUE,   alpha = 35,   beta = 45 )  layout_igraph_multilevel(   g,   type = "all",   FUN1,   FUN2,   params1 = NULL,   params2 = NULL,   ignore_iso = TRUE,   alpha = 35,   beta = 45,   circular )

title: multilevel layout — layout_multilevel
text: g igraph object. Must vertex attribute "lvl" 1 2. type one "", "separate","fix1" "fix2". see details FUN1 type="separate", layout function used level 1 FUN2 type="separate", layout function used level 2 params1 named list parameters FUN1 params2 named list parameters FUN2 ignore_iso treatment isolates within levels. see details project2D logical. Defaults TRUE (project 2D). alpha angle isometric projection 0 90 beta angle isometric projection 0 90 circular used

title: multilevel layout — layout_multilevel
text: matrix xy coordinates

title: multilevel layout — layout_multilevel
text: algorithm internally computes 3D layout level separate y-plane. layout projected 2D via isometric mapping, controlled parameters alpha beta. may take adjusting alpha beta find good perspective. type="", layout computed complete network. type="separate", two user specified layout algorithms (FUN1 FUN2) used levels. named lists param1 param2 can used set parameters FUN1 FUN2. option helpful situations different structural features levels emphasized. type="fix1" type="fix2" one level layouts fixed. one calculated optimizing inter level ties, drawn (almost) vertical. ignore_iso parameter controls handling isolates. TRUE, nodes without inter level edges ignored layout process added end. FALSE left unchanged layout_igraph_* function used directly. used argument plotting 'igraph'.

title: multilevel layout — layout_multilevel
code: library(igraph) data("multilvl_ex")  # compute a layout for the whole network xy <- layout_as_multilevel(multilvl_ex, type = "all", alpha = 25, beta = 45)  # compute a layout for each level separately and combine them xy <- layout_as_multilevel(multilvl_ex,     type = "separate",     FUN1 = layout_as_backbone,     FUN2 = layout_with_stress,     alpha = 25, beta = 45 )

title: graphlayouts 1.0.2

title: graphlayouts 1.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-09-19 removed use %u% (#70)

title: graphlayouts 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-05-01 added install oaqc readme(#52) fixed grammar Description (#53) made dynamic layout example reproducible (#54) replaced 1:length seq_along (#55) added contributing guide (#56) added tests (#60)

title: graphlayouts 0.8.4
text: CRAN release: 2022-11-24 added unit tests added package level description

title: graphlayouts 0.8.3
text: CRAN release: 2022-10-20 fixed error disconnected graphs explicit weights vector (#47) added proper citation

title: graphlayouts 0.8.2
text: CRAN release: 2022-09-29 fixed error large graphs (#45) added layout_with_focus_group() layout_with_centrality_group() (#46)

title: graphlayouts 0.8.1
text: CRAN release: 2022-08-11 added warning layout_as_backbone() graph disconnected contains isolates

title: graphlayouts 0.8.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-01-03 added layout_with_umap()

title: graphlayouts 0.7.2
text: CRAN release: 2021-11-21 fixed description bbox layout_with_stress fixed bug layout_with_stress3D produced 2D layout

title: graphlayouts 0.7.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-10-26 restoring old seed using stress layout

title: graphlayouts 0.7.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-04-25 added layout_as_multilevel() multilevel networks added layout_with_stress3D() layout_with_constrained_stress3D() 3D layouts fixed crash layout_as_backbone() graph loops (#32)

title: graphlayouts 0.6.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-03-09 added layout_with_constrained_stress() added fixed random seed stress (stress deterministic produces layout translation/rotation) speedup layout_with_sparse_stress() layout_with_pmds() “smarter” distance calculation speedup layout_with_sparse_stress() using precomputed distances layout_with_pmds() speedup layout_with_stress() dynamically switching layout_with_pmds() initialisation large graphs

title: graphlayouts 0.5.0
text: CRAN release: 2019-08-20 BREAKING CHANGE: removed qgraph(). Now part ggraph. POSSIBLE BREAKING CHANGE: layout_with_focus() now also returns distance focus node changed filenames (doesn’t effect functionality) added layout_as_dynamic() longitudinal network data removed gbpand scales dependency moved oaqc suggest edge weights now supported layout_with_stress() layout_with_focus() added layout_with_pmds() (Pivot MDS large graphs) added layout_with_sparse_stress() (“stress large graphs”)

title: graphlayouts 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2019-07-04 added checks multiple directed edges layout_as_backbone() faster implementation reweighting layout_as_backbone() minor bug fixes “stress” calculation

title: graphlayouts 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2019-04-05 added examples documentation

title: graphlayouts 0.0.5.9000
text: changed name smglr graphlayouts (sorry) added layout_with_eigen() layouts can now used directly ggraph, e.g. ggraph(g,layout="stress")+... added documentation, examples references
